Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go

nodes.body: Reopened from https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/6112 so that CI will run.
@eric-wieser @riccardobrasca Thanks for taking a look at this! Any additional changes requested?

> @eric-wieser @riccardobrasca Thanks for taking a look at this! Any additional changes requested?

Sorry for my late reply, I am on vacation. I will try to have a look at this tomorrow.

> I pushed some golfing just to give an idea of what's possible. More could be done but it's not necessary: the most important thing is to make sure we're happy with the statements (and names) as opposed to the proofs (which are fine anyway).
> 
> There is just one final point relevant here which is that we try not to use the subtraction on the natural numbers if we can avoid it (because zero is absorbing and so it behaves badly).
> 
> Thus it would be nice to avoid the `k - i` appearing in the statements of the two main theorems. The tool to do this is the sum over the anti-diagonal.
> 
> For an example, see [Commute.add_pow](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Data/Nat/Choose/Sum.html#Commute.add_pow) which is uses the bad subtraction versus its better variant [Commute.add_pow'](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Data/Nat/Choose/Sum.html#Commute.add_pow') which does not.
> 
> It's not essential to state it this way as part of this work. I'll return to look over this again tomorrow.

@ocfnash I've rewritten everything using `filter` on `antidiagonal`. There were some helper lemmas that were arguably more simply stated using `range` and didn't resort to subtraction on Nat, but it doesn't really matter much given that they're entirely internal to the proof. Let me know if you have any additional suggestions, and thanks very much for being willing to spend so much time going over this PR!

A few final suggestions. I think there's still quite a bit of scope for golfing the proofs but the statements of the main theorems are now great I think.

Thanks for all the work.

bors d+
lgtm!
lgtm!

This is close to being ready. I have added a bunch of minor suggestions.

There are further naming suggestions I could make but I think the author can likely make them based on the examples I have explicitly given.

I also suggest that the contents of the `section PowerSum` be moved to the file `RingTheory.MvPolynomial.Symmetric`.

I pushed some golfing just to give an idea of what's possible. More could be done but it's not necessary: the most important thing is to make sure we're happy with the statements (and names) as opposed to the proofs (which are fine anyway).

There is just one final point relevant here which is that we try not to use the subtraction on the natural numbers if we can avoid it (because zero is absorbing and so it behaves badly).

Thus it would be nice to avoid the `k - i` appearing in the statements of the two main theorems. The tool to do this is the sum over the anti-diagonal.

For an example, see [Commute.add_pow](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Data/Nat/Choose/Sum.html#Commute.add_pow) which is uses the bad subtraction versus its better variant [Commute.add_pow'](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Data/Nat/Choose/Sum.html#Commute.add_pow') which does not.

It's not essential to state it this way as part of this work. I'll return to look over this again tomorrow.
A few more tweaks, mostly style.

A few final suggestions. I think there's still quite a bit of scope for golfing the proofs but the statements of the main theorems are now great I think.

Thanks for all the work.

bors d+
Can you add a short explanation about what a power sum is?
Done! In the notation section
Can you use [zeilberger1984] in this comment?
Done!
I'd probably drop this, as it's not useful in the editor (where you can just read the source) or the web docs (where this is written on every lemma).
I just copied it from Mathlib/RingTheory/MvPolynomial/Symmetric.lean. I can drop it!
What does the `T` stand for here? Note that the naming convention does not allow `_`s in `def` names; so this should be `tMap` or something.

[It's just the symbol used for this map in the paper.](https://sites.math.rutgers.edu/~zeilberg/mamarimY/Zeilberger_y1984_p319.pdf)

I can come up with a better name.
I've renamed it `pairMap`, but I'm open to better nomenclature if you have suggestions.

```suggestion
* `MvPolynomial.psum`: The degree-`n` power sum evaluated at the elements of `s`.
```

```suggestion
* `MvPolynomial.NewtonIdentities.esymm_recurrence`: a recurrence relation for the kth elementary
  symmetric polynomial in terms of lower degree elementary symmetric polynomials and power sums.
```

hopefully the indentation is right

```suggestion
def psum (s : Multiset R) (n : ℕ) : R := (s.map (· ^ n : R → R)).sum
```

another (syntactically equal) way to write it - your call
may be nice to have lemmas for `psum_zero` and `psum_one`
Added `psum_zero`
Added `psum_one`
weird place for the comment, I think it's fine to just leave it in the docstrings or closer to the actual mathematical statement
Removed

```suggestion
@[simp] theorem pairMap_involutive : (pairMap σ).Involutive := by
  intro t
  rw [pairMap, pairMap]
```

This doesn't break the file at all and just puts it in a neater box.
Done!

the next few lemma names don't really fit the conventions, but I don't particularly mind it because I think they're mostly internal to the proof - do you forsee these lemmas being used anywhere else? If not, I think it may be worth making most of the stuff in this section `private`.
I think making it private is a good idea. I went through and addressed the naming conventions and made private everything that was strictly internal to the proof.

```suggestion
/-- **Newton's identities** give a recurrence relation for the kth elementary symmetric polynomial
```
is it worth having a version that gives you the explicit value of `esymm σ R k`?
`esymm σ R k` is already defined in explicit form, no?
I guess, yes - I'm not sure how these recursions are used, but I imagined that they'd be used to rewrite some explicit `esymm` into the lower order ones.
They're arguably more useful for rewriting `psum` in lower-order terms. I might just add a `psum_recurrence` result as a corollary.
Okay, I've added `psum_recurrence`.
[Example problems from contest mathematics that use the result in the `psum_recurrence` form in combination with Vieta's formulas](https://artofproblemsolving.com/wiki/index.php/Newton%27s_Sums)

this is usually spelt as `Fintype.card \sigma`! (bigger review later)

Also, I'd say probably preferrable to use `univ (\alpha = \sigma)` instead of `@`, for other contexts' reference
Fixed!
again for future's sake, don't mind if you leave it like this as it is private: something referring to `pairMap` should be named e.g. `pairMap_mem_pairs`
Done!

```suggestion
@[simp]
theorem rename_psum (n : ℕ) (e : σ ≃ τ) : rename e (psum σ R n) = psum τ R n := by
```

I think this will help you simplify a few proofs below (e.g., avoid silliness like `t ∈ univ` arising).
```suggestion

@[simp]
private lemma mem_pairs (k : ℕ) (t : Finset σ × σ) :
    t ∈ pairs σ k ↔ card t.fst ≤ k ∧ (card t.fst = k → t.snd ∈ t.fst) := by
  simp [pairs]

```

I think these should help simplify things below:
```suggestion

private lemma pairMap_of_snd_mem_fst {t : Finset σ × σ} (h : t.snd ∈ t.fst) :
    pairMap σ t = (t.fst.erase t.snd, t.snd) := by
  simp [pairMap, h]

private lemma pairMap_of_snd_nmem_fst {t : Finset σ × σ} (h : t.snd ∉ t.fst) :
    pairMap σ t = (cons t.snd t.fst h, t.snd) := by
  simp [pairMap, h]

```
Added this, will simplify where possible

```suggestion
@[simp] private theorem pairMap_involutive : (pairMap σ).Involutive := by
```

Names for `def`s can be what we like but we try to name `theorem`s based on the type of the hypotheses and conclusion.
```suggestion
private theorem weight_eq_zero_of_pairMapEqSelf (t : Finset σ × σ) (h : t ∈ pairs σ k)
```
Done!

To avoid having to unfold the definition:
```suggestion

lemma psum_def (n : ℕ) : psum σ R n = ∑ i, X i ^ n := rfl

```
Done!

Unused (maybe a relic from earlier version):
```suggestion
```
Removed!
Done!

I thought I could golf this but all I got was:
```suggestion
  rw [← eq_neg_self_iff, ← add_eq_zero_iff_eq_neg]
  nth_rw 2 [← h2]
  exact weight_add_weight_pairMap σ R t h
```
Take it or leave it
Done!

I think better just to inline this at the single place it is used.
```suggestion
```
Done!

```suggestion
    (fun t h ↦ mt $ weight_eq_zero_of_pairMapEqSelf σ R t h) (pair_map_mem_pairs σ)
```
Done! Nice trick with `$`. Going to have to remember that.

Again, trying to name this based on type would yield something like:
```suggestion
private theorem sum_filter_pairs_eq_sum_powersetLen_sum
    (k : ℕ) (f : Finset σ × σ → MvPolynomial σ R) :
```
Done!

Note that this is a theorem and not a definition so we should try to name it based on the type (so "recurrence" has no place here or below). Also, I think the following is a more useful statement:
```suggestion
theorem mul_esymm_eq_sum (k : ℕ) :
    k * esymm σ R k = (-1)^(k+1) * ∑ i in range k, (-1) ^ i * esymm σ R i * psum σ R (k - i) := by
```
Done!

```suggestion
theorem psum_eq_mul_esymm_sub_sum (k : ℕ) (h : k > 0) : psum σ R k = (-1) ^ (k + 1) * (k * esymm σ R k) -
```
Done!

Apart from rare exceptions, we always use `<` and `≤` instead of `>` and `≥` since it's occasionally awkward having syntactically different but definitionally equal things floating around:
```suggestion
    have h3 : 1 ≤ card t.fst := lt_iff_add_one_le.mp (card_pos.mpr ⟨t.snd, h1⟩)
```

```suggestion
in terms of lower degree elementary symmetric polynomials and power sums.

The recurrence arises by splitting off the `i = k` term from the identity
  `∑ ᵢ₊ⱼ₌ₖ (-1)ⁱeᵢpⱼ = 0`. -/
```
It would also be good to add an informal sketch of the proof in the file doc string.

```suggestion
    rw [esymm_to_weight σ R k, esymm_mul_psum_to_weight σ R k, eq_comm, ← sub_eq_zero, sub_eq_add_neg,
    neg_mul_eq_neg_mul, neg_eq_neg_one_mul ((-1 : MvPolynomial σ R) ^ k)]
```
The `eq_comm` shouldn't be necessary but I was too lazy to eliminate it.

```suggestion
theorem psum_eq_mul_esymm_sub_sum (k : ℕ) (h : 0 < k) : psum σ R k =
```

I think the two main results should just be in the `MvPolynomial` namespace.
```suggestion

end NewtonIdentities

```
(you'll have to fiddle with `variable` and `open NewtonIdentities` after applying this change)
Done!

```suggestion
* `MvPolynomial.mul_esymm_eq_sum`: a recurrence relation for the kth elementary
```

I think this is slightly better:
```suggestion
    ∑ a in (antidiagonal k).filter (fun a ↦ a.fst ∈ Set.Ioo 0 k),
      (-1) ^ a.fst * esymm σ R a.fst * psum σ R a.snd := by
```
(and it should also eliminate the `a.fst ≥ 1` below which I would otherwise suggest tweaking)
Done!

How about we also add the special `k = Fintype.card σ` case:
```suggestion

theorem sum_antidiagonal_card_esymm_psum_eq_zero :
    ∑ a in antidiagonal (Fintype.card σ), (-1) ^ a.fst * esymm σ R a.fst * psum σ R a.snd = 0 := by
  let k := Fintype.card σ
  suffices : (-1 : MvPolynomial σ R) ^ (k + 1) *
    ∑ a in antidiagonal k, (-1) ^ a.fst * esymm σ R a.fst * psum σ R a.snd = 0
  · simpa using this
  simp [← sum_filter_add_sum_filter_not (antidiagonal k) (fun a ↦ a.fst < k), ← mul_esymm_eq_sum,
    mul_add, ← mul_assoc, ← pow_add, mul_comm ↑k (esymm σ R k)]

```
Done!

I just noticed that this argument relies on `eq_neg_self_iff` so it doesn't quite go through for all commutative rings, which is a shame. I think we should at least capture this in the doc string:
```suggestion
## TODO

Remove the `[NoZeroDivisors R] [CharZero R]` hypotheses

```
I removed the hypotheses by adding the suggested `pairMap_ne_self` lemma, so this is actually unnecessary!

This is a slightly strange lemma because `weight σ R k t` is just a monomial (up to a sign) and so is non-zero (#6541 might make this easier to prove). A more natural statement would be:
```lean
private theorem pairMap_ne_self {k : ℕ} (t : Finset σ × σ) (h : t ∈ pairs σ k) :
    pairMap σ t ≠ t :=
```
Done!
This is extremely concise; it would be nice to expand it.
Added a little more detail!

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(RingTheory/MvPolynomial/NewtonIdentities): Add proof of Newton's identities

nodes.body: Reopened from https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/6112 so that CI will run.
@eric-wieser @riccardobrasca Thanks for taking a look at this! Any additional changes requested?
lgtm!

> @eric-wieser @riccardobrasca Thanks for taking a look at this! Any additional changes requested?

Sorry for my late reply, I am on vacation. I will try to have a look at this tomorrow.

This is close to being ready. I have added a bunch of minor suggestions.

There are further naming suggestions I could make but I think the author can likely make them based on the examples I have explicitly given.

I also suggest that the contents of the `section PowerSum` be moved to the file `RingTheory.MvPolynomial.Symmetric`.

I pushed some golfing just to give an idea of what's possible. More could be done but it's not necessary: the most important thing is to make sure we're happy with the statements (and names) as opposed to the proofs (which are fine anyway).

There is just one final point relevant here which is that we try not to use the subtraction on the natural numbers if we can avoid it (because zero is absorbing and so it behaves badly).

Thus it would be nice to avoid the `k - i` appearing in the statements of the two main theorems. The tool to do this is the sum over the anti-diagonal.

For an example, see [Commute.add_pow](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Data/Nat/Choose/Sum.html#Commute.add_pow) which is uses the bad subtraction versus its better variant [Commute.add_pow'](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Data/Nat/Choose/Sum.html#Commute.add_pow') which does not.

It's not essential to state it this way as part of this work. I'll return to look over this again tomorrow.

> I pushed some golfing just to give an idea of what's possible. More could be done but it's not necessary: the most important thing is to make sure we're happy with the statements (and names) as opposed to the proofs (which are fine anyway).
> 
> There is just one final point relevant here which is that we try not to use the subtraction on the natural numbers if we can avoid it (because zero is absorbing and so it behaves badly).
> 
> Thus it would be nice to avoid the `k - i` appearing in the statements of the two main theorems. The tool to do this is the sum over the anti-diagonal.
> 
> For an example, see [Commute.add_pow](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Data/Nat/Choose/Sum.html#Commute.add_pow) which is uses the bad subtraction versus its better variant [Commute.add_pow'](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Data/Nat/Choose/Sum.html#Commute.add_pow') which does not.
> 
> It's not essential to state it this way as part of this work. I'll return to look over this again tomorrow.

@ocfnash I've rewritten everything using `filter` on `antidiagonal`. There were some helper lemmas that were arguably more simply stated using `range` and didn't resort to subtraction on Nat, but it doesn't really matter much given that they're entirely internal to the proof. Let me know if you have any additional suggestions, and thanks very much for being willing to spend so much time going over this PR!
A few more tweaks, mostly style.
